title: Idol Immersion:No More Immersion Of Idols In River Ganga And Its Tributaries, Says Government; Violators To Be Fined Rs 50,000
text:
No More Immersion Of Idols In River Ganga And Its Tributaries, Says Government; Violators To Be Fined Rs 50,000

No More Immersion Of Idols In River Ganga And Its Tributaries, Says Government; Violators To Be Fined Rs 50,000

Immersion of idols and puja materials including flowers in rivers has been an integral part of various Hindu festivals for ages.

But during the upcoming festival season, the Central Government has banned immersion of idols in the Hindu holy river of Ganga and its tributaries.

BCCL

The National Mission For Clean Ganga (NMCG) has issued directives to 15 Ganga basin states banning immersion of idols in the Ganga or its tributaries during festivals, including Dussehra, Diwali, Chhath and Saraswati Puja, The Indian Express reported.

NMCG, the nodal agency tasked with cleaning the Hindu holy river has reportedly issued a 15-point directive including cordoning off ghats to prevent the immersion of idols in the Ganga and its tributaries.

BCCL

Accordingly, the immersion of idols using synthetic material/ non-biodegradable material, Plaster of Paris (POP), baked clay, resin fibers, and thermocol have been banned. Besides, the use of toxic and non-biodegradable chemical dyes or synthetic paints for the painting of idols has also been strictly prohibited.

The NMCG issued the directives after a meeting between NMCG officials and representatives of Uttarakhand, UP, Bihar, Jharkhand and West Bengal last month.

The report also added that the directive has been sent to other states including Delhi, Himachal Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Haryana, and Rajasthan.

The chief secretaries of the 11 states have been asked to submit an action taken report within seven days from the end of each festival.

BCCL

The development comes as the NMCG is anticipating a spike in the amount of pollutants in River Ganga as the result of the immersions during the festival season.

The NMCG was set up as ‘Flagship Programme’ by the Union Government in June 2014 with a budget outlay of Rs.20,000 Crore to accomplish the twin objectives of effective abatement of pollution, conservation, and rejuvenation of River Ganga, which had been left in a poor state due to the pollution.

BCCL

Even though the government has claimed that significant progress has been made the data from the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) from earlier this year stated that water from River Ganga is absolutely unfit for "direct drinking" and only seven spots from where it passes can be consumed after disinfection. According to the data with the CPCB, most of the Ganga river water in the Uttar Pradesh-West Bengal stretch was unfit for drinking and bathing.
